trustfund:
TF094444-EVALUATION OF THE IMPACT OF THE
            PROJECT ON WOMEN

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Community-Driven
            Development (CDD) Project for Haiti were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory; risk to development
            outcome was substantial; Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory and borrower performance was also moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: project
            structures which run parallel to municipal governments to
            promote local development are a common feature of CDD
            projects but efforts are needed from the start to link them
            to municipal government and build cooperation, joint
            planning and development synergies. To ensure Subprojects
            (SP) and institutional development sustainability, SP
            selection should be aligned to the extent possible with
            central government and local government priorities and
            plans. The quality and size of SPs are important for the
            sustainability and credibility of the whole program. The
            menu of eligible SPs should reflect national and
            international development experience and not finance SPs
            with high probable failure rates. Leadership training for
            women in preparation for community leadership roles should
            be part of the gender strategy. The Bank's fiduciary
            procurement and financial management requirements applied to
            communities moved the focus away from sound technical
            implementation and organizational skills development. CDD is
            arguably the best instrument in a centralized state where
            working through the ministries is difficult and the
            decentralization agenda has stalled.
